												A truly unique experience with fun combat and great narrative. The game's opening sequence is one of the most memorable and immerses you into the world right from the start. The narrative is mainly driven by audio diaries that the player picks up, so there is a lot of exploration involved if you want to learn story of Rapture. Collecting these is optional, but I would definitely recommend taking the time to explore the environment and collecting these audio diaries for a more satisfying story experience.The combat in the game has good variety because of the many different plasmids (essentially superpowers) you unlock throughout the game. The variety in the combat can also be attributed to the diversity in weapons and the different Gene Tonics (powerups) that the player can equip. (The weapons  can be accessed by the number keys/scroll wheel or by the weapon/plasmid menu, so there isn't any swapping/equipping weapons in and out.) My only gripes with the game are the hacking, which can get extremely frustrating towards the end of the game due to RNG, and the gameplay involving the research camera. The research camera felt like unecessary work and was just overall annoying. I would definitely recommend this game if you want a unique FPS with a great story and have the desire/patience to explore the levels of the game. I would not recommend this game if you do not have the patience to explore or if you want a fast-paced FPS. P.S. Play this version instead of the Remastered. Just finished a playthrough of the Remastered and it definitely is not worth it due to the bugs and the ridiculous amount of random crashes. (I am running an i5-6600K and a GTX 1060)

One of my very favorite games...Bioshock.This is one of those games that's an experience. The second i started the game i couldn't stop playing it, I marathoned the whole thing till finished and i had played it on the xbox too. Everything i'm saying is my opinion of course, but i truly believe everyone should experience Bioshock at some point and jouney through Rapture and witness this masterpiece, you can't relive the first play through again. So, would you Kindly hear me out?So going into Bioshock my tastes suit this game perfectly, everything about this game is brilliant. I loved everything about it. the very detailed and well written story, the lore, the atmosphere, the city of Rapture itself, the characters, gameplay, and of course the MUSIC!The Score for bioshock is perhaps one of the best soundtracks i've ever heard. It suits the game so much and helps tell the story, it's beautiful, lonely, and haunting, just like the game's atmosphere and story. The sheer tension before a battle where a big daddy and some splicers could be around the corner while a lonley cello or violin solo tugs at your soul just helps complete this masterpiece, it's absolutely breathtaking. Another thing to mention in the subject of music is 40's era music on radios while you explore Rapture, which older music and early jazz i just so happen to love. like this ink spots for example. I think this is a very nice, wonderful touch to, again, capture the atmosphere of this city which is like a character itself. Another addition I love is the song "Beyond the Sea" as it occurs in the beginning a very nice touch in deed considering Rapture is underwater. One touch i love is the Fonts! It gives me so much nostalgia because its like the same font used in Batman the Animated series! one of my all time favorite shows. I believe the font is called Plaza, i love it alot it's co classy and has a retro 40's look to it, very nice. I love all of the small details like story telling through items or locations in the game, you don't always need words or dialogue to tell great stories.With the release of the remaster, it seems slightly improved look wise, although i don't know about performance wise i haven't played the remaster enough to see. with the combat Bioshock 2 improved a couple of things in combat like using your weapon and plasmid at the same time was one improvment for example. one thing I always hated was this awful mouse acceleration, it was so annoying, thats one of the only negatives.Depending on your actions you'll get an ending based on what your choices in the game were. NO SPOILERS here, but i will say that I really loved the ending, I usually don't cry that much at the end of games (depending on the game), but the ending made me cry... alot, a happy cry though. This will conclude the review, sorry if it was really long and rambly, but it gets to the point where a game is such a masterpiece, so breathtaking on an emotional level, that i think it's no longer a game... it's a priceless work of Art. Games in General are Art.Thanks for reading my review i Strongly recommend everyone experience this Masterpiece of a game. a true Gem that's unique and different to most shootersI rank it 10/10 Big Boy Review scoreThanks

4, 2015
												This is the first time I have played the first Bioshock and I have to say it amazed me.The world, the story and the gameplay is really something special. The story itself takes place in Rapture. This is an Atlantis-like steampunk world where a disaster has happened. You go down into Rapture and have to figure things out to help the people down there, but as you play you will come to understand the character you are playing as and the world around you.At first it will comes across as 'do this', 'do that' but you will come to understand the meaning behind all of it. The story for the most part is told through voice recordings (So no 60 minute long cutscenes).You also find old voice messages left by people before they died, that tell you more about the backstory of the world. The further I got into the game, the more interesting it became to me and after I had completed the game I was searching the internet to find out more about Rapture.The gameplay is fun, the weapons feel nice to use, but occasionally I felt that my character moved too slowly. I played the game on medium difficulty and still found the combat challenging enough. I would recommend that if you play on this difficulty to spam E on every searchable container to get ammo, health, cash etc.This is because medium can become boring as you often don't have enough ammo and keep having to respawn at Vita Chambers.Due to these Vita Chambers, I sometimes got the feeling I was playing a multiplayer game. Because when I died I would just respawn and have to run back to where the enemies were. So death feels like it has little consequence.Many people complain about the amount of hacking you have to do if you don't want to be shredded instantly by the turrets.At first I didn't really have any problems with it and hacked every object that could be hacked, but as I progressed through the game I got really tired of it.As well as guns the game also has Plasmids, which are special powers that you can perform with your characters left hand.These Plasmids, like your guns, can be upgraded.The RPG elements in this game really makes you consider which items should be taken with you and which should be left behind.The world has this great Atlantis vibe. Everything in the world of Rapture is enclosed, which helps the game to achieve no pop-in and have great looking environments. These still look great after all this time because of the attention to detail, time and effort put in to them. You only see some problems when you get too close to certain textures. Because of the narrowness of the environments and the use of audio, you get this creepy haunted house feeling.A feeling that around every corner something strange could happen.I only wish that the game had given us more open environments and that the watery world outside of Rapture was more interesting to look at.The A.I. makes good use of its environment. For example, when they are low on health they will run to a nearby healing machine, or if they are on fire they will jump into water to extinguish themselves.The enemies are well realised with great acrobatic animations and sophisticated A.I. The only things that feel clunky to me are the enemy death animations and how the physics objects react.Like, when you hit an object with your wrench, it flies away jerkily through the air, as if you are viewing it at 10 FPS.Note: I would recommend saving every time before alt/shift + tabbing. The game sometimes crashed, when I did that. ( windows 7 64bit )Final thoughts:This was my first time playing through the original Bioshock and it is amazing.There is really alot of creativity and care put into this AAA game that you don't often see.Even if you own Bioshock 2 or Bioshock:Infinite (Infinite has nothing to do with Bioshock 1 and 2) I would still recommend playing it because of the story and how well the game has aged.

												My favorite game from the 360/PS3 era.  When this came out it was a breath of fresh air in art direction and pacing.  The plot is amazing, including one of the best reveals in gaming when you meet Mr. Andrew Ryan.  You can explore a glorious underwater city that has gone from paradise to madness through the in game characters you meet and the audio journals you collect.  There are some real standout characters both from physical design and voice acting standpoints.  Who doesn't remember Sander Cohen after they play this game once!  The graphics still hold up today (just finished a playthrough 1/9/2014) with both the characters and backgrounds having great detail and art.  Enemies variation is good in the beginning, but repeat a little to often near the end, just as most shooters do.  Of course, the game has the iconic big daddy fights that are a lot of fun and a real challenge on hard difficulty.        I don't think the actual shooting is anything too special,  You get pretty standard weapon choices (Pistol, machine gun, shotgun, rocket launcher, yawn, zzzzz)  but you do get a lot of cool spell type abilities called Plasmids and get to upgrade each weapon and Plasmid twice.  There are multiple ammo types for each gun as well as hackable enemies, so for what the shooting lacks in weight and badass weaponry it makes up for in sheer variety.  You can literally not play this game the same way twice.   Be warned the graphics always seemed a little more glitchy on PC than it did on my dearly departed XBOX.  I've had occasional frame rate jumps and the electric chemical thrower would cause graphical glitches on my pair of playthroughs on PC.  Check the forums as this game can be a real pain to get working on your modern OS.    The game gets my highest recommendation.  You will see this for $5.00 every once in a while on Steam.  If you didn't buy it for that price you would be a damn fool.

												This has got to be one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. Gameplay was good, the environment is literally breathtaking, and the story is magnificent.You play as Jack, whose plane goes down in the middle of the Atlantic ocean near a lighthouse. The lighthouse is actually the gateway to the underwater city of Rapture. Or it ruins, anyway. Rapture, the brain child of industrialist Andrew Ryan, was supposed to be a paradise for the common man, but not all was well in paradise. Civil unrest, class warfare, and add unmonitored sciencetific discoveries to the mix and things got real very fast. Plasmids, tonics that give humans super powers so to speak, is powered by a substance called "ADAM". But it destroys the mind with repeated abuse and now it's aftermath roams the streets.When you arrive, you seem to be at the tail end of the Rapture Civil War (a war between classes which quickly turned into a game of "Who Can Splice More") and you are almost immedietly contacted by a man named Atlas, who promises to help you escape Rapture. Now you must navigate through the city to find a way out. But don't get too comfortable in this city. Not all is as it seems and everyone is trying to get their hands on you.What I loved most about BioShock is that the main story isn't the only story. You learn about the city, it's people, and what caused paradise to literally sink. You learn how far we as humans will go to get what we desire and just what lines some will cross to enhance the human race.Are you a man or a slave? A savior or a splicer? Make your choices wisely, because in the end, your choices make you.

TL;DR at BottomIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!9/10Necessary Purchase "A man chooses, a slave obeys." -Andrew Ryan                          Bioshock is a first-person shooter developed and published by 2K games. The game takes place in a sub-oceanic city called Rapture. The city was created by an entrepreneur by the name of Andrew Ryan who created the city with the idea that anyone could be great and do amazing things if they worked hard for it. The city used to be a revolutionary society populated by the best and brightest but now it's filled with splicers,people who have used too much Adam and have gone insane because of it. Adam is a sort of drug produced by a type of sea slug and it functions as a sort of cancer-like disease that replaces native cells with unstable stem versions. Adam is what makes the wheels of rapture turn and you use it to buy new plasmids or upgrade abilities at a gatherers garden shop. Plasmids are basically spells you can use and your "mana" pool is called eve. There are so many different kinds of plasmids that they make combat incredibly fun and varied as well. Each plasmid is unique and no two will feel the same. Bioshock also has Gene Tonics, which are basically just passives that fall under 1 of 3 categories: Physical, Engineering, or Combat. Each tonic offers helpful passive bonuses that can completely alter how you decide to play the game. For example, if you pick up the right tonics then you can basically turn Bioshock into a stealth game. The entirety of Bioshock is incredibly creepy but honestly I never got truly scared due to the fact that the developers included only 2-3 jumpscares and opted to use legitimate horror rather than these cheap alternatives.


YouTube™ Video: 60 Second Reviews: Bioshock 

			Views: 1,805		

			Bioshock is a FPS set in the underwater city of Rapture and it also has quite a few RPG elements such as customizable abilities and upgrades.		

As I mentioned before Bioshock is an FPS which means that you're going to be doing lot's of shooting and boy is it fun. The guns in Bioshock don't really feel that good and almost all of them have very poor control and are hard to aim with.  Bioshocks main strength comes from the enemies and the weapons that you can wield. There are loads of different enemies to fight,each with varying strength and you will have a plethora of weapons to slay them with. Weapons from a chemical thrower loaded with napalm to a shotgun with electric rounds every weapon serves a purpose and as you progress you'll begin to find that out. Each weapon has different ammo types that can be loaded in to the weapon such as proximity mines for the grenade launcher or AP rounds for the machine gun. There are U-Invent stations spread throughout the levels and at these stations you can craft various new items such as new plasmids or ammo types. About halfway through the game you get the camera and this will allow you to take pictures of enemies and for taking these pictues you gain bonuses. For example, if you take pictures of the Big Daddies then you can unlock extra damage and loot to use against them. This is an incredibly unique system and really enhances the combat with all sorts of bonuses to keep in mind. This brings me to my main problem with the combat in Bioshock: Its old. Now don't get me wrong I love old games because most the time they're just flat out better games but here the old and dated controls really kills the game in parts. The options menu  is fairly lacking and the graphics options may cause some problems but my main issue is the sensitivity. The sensitivity completely ♥♥♥♥ed me over in combat because it's always too high and there isn't a good scale built into the game. No matter what I did even on the lowest it was still too fast for me and ruined combat half the time. Now,when you die you respawn at a Vita-Chamber with no penalty. This may be seen as too easy but due to how dated this game feels I think it allows people to advance through this amazing game no matter what and not be held back by dated controls and gameplay.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=587209283 "Plasmids changed everything. They destroyed our bodies, our minds; we couldn't handle it. Best friends butchering one another, babies strangled in cribs... the whole city went to Hell." -AtlasSo you may know Bioshock as a game with one of the biggest twists of all time and a story to match. Bioshock's story is absolutely phenomenal and borders on perfect with it's deep characters, unique setting, and one of the best twists in gaming history. The story is amazing on it's own but you soon come to realise that every single thing in Rapture has it's own story to it. The splicers have a story, the Vita-Chamber you respawn in has a story, and , most importantly of all, you have a story. Spread about Rapture are audio diaries which are little audio recordings that shed light on what Rapture truly is and how it came to be such a decrepit pit at the bottom of the ocean.Rapture's environments are some of the best I have ever seen, especially for a game thats 9 years old. You experience a variety of levels and environment types throughout your time in Rapture and every one is memorable and unique. You also begin to get the feeling that, contrary to what Ryan says, Rapture is falling apart all around you and there's nothing you do but make it worse. Also the level design in Bioshock is so perfect that you can't help but look around. Each level has loads of little nooks and side areas where you can pick up a new Tonic or type of ammo. Eventually you'll piece together what really happened and then just when you think you have it all figured out, it all gets thrown on it's head as everything around you begins to fall apart.TL;DRBioshock is an absolute masterpiece of a game that will leave you aching for more of it's revolutionary storytelling and creative combat mechanics.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

												An experience at a level that most games try to reach, but seldom do. This game has it all. A gripping story line, amazing audio, and graphics. For being released in 2007, the graphics are on par with newer titles. With 20 hours of game play you will not be disappointed. Rapture is skillfully designed, and is truly a work of art. The dark environments are easy to get immersed in, and fit nicely in the horror genre. The game is based in the 1960s, and with the music and visuals you are reminded of that, but the game has a very futuristic feel.There are plenty of weapons, as well as plasmids to use. Different weapons and plasmids work best at defeating certain enemies.  But this game is not your standard shooter. With the ability to save up "Adam" to boost your skills, weapons and plasmids like a rpg, just not as complex. There's also crafting involved with items you collect throughout the game, again not to the depth of a true rpg. You have freedom to explore the confines of Rapture, and I suggest that you do. Be sure to pick up all the audio recordings to follow the story, as most of the story line plays out through these recordings. You will also find needed information in the recordings. You can replay all the recordings by using the "M" if you miss something or simply cannot hear what they are saying do to background noise.The biggest downfall of this game, the originality, the dark and macabre world setting maybe too obscure for the average gamer to appreciate.If you enjoy horror/survival games, then this is a definite must have, as well as a nice addition to any gamers collection.

content:
r 7, 2015
												In early 2010, film critic Roger Ebert published an article regarding his position on video games as an artistic medium. Early in the article, Ebert firmly expresses his view on the matter: “Let me just say that no video gamer now living will survive long enough to experience the medium as an art form.” As much as I respect the late Roger Ebert, I have to disagree with this statement because gamers living today have survived to see at least one game rise above the rest as a work of art. The game in question is Bioshock, a first person shooter that combines exquisite storytelling, impressive presentation, and innovative gameplay into one cohesive unit that stands with any novel, painting, or movie as a piece of fine art.	Bioshock begins with the player’s character, a silent protagonist named Jack, surviving a plane crash in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. With nowhere else to go, Jack swims to a nearby islet occupied by a large lighthouse. Jack takes refuge inside the structure and discovers a small bathysphere that takes him to the game’s main setting, the massive underwater city of Rapture. According to a recording played in the bathysphere, Rapture was conceived by a business magnate named Andrew Ryan, who built the city with the vision of a utopian community where one could achieve greatness without any interference from outside forces, such as government or religion. However, upon arriving in Rapture, the player soon finds out that things did not go exactly as Ryan planned. The city now lies in ruin and all of its living residents have become murderous lunatics that lash out at anything that moves. Aided via radio by a mysterious man named Atlas, Jack must now explore rapture and escape with his life. 	What makes this game stand out from others is that the player has full control of Jack during the entire experience. By immediately relinquishing control, Bioshock immerses the player in a captivating tale of freewill and madness that slowly reveals itself over the course of the game. In addition to scripted events, such as the masterfully executed opening, the player can listen to audio logs left behind by the once sane citizens of Rapture. These optional logs give the player deeper insight into the lives of Rapture’s residents and the events that led to the city’s downfall. 	Ryan himself adds philosophical depth to the game’s already rich narrative. He exudes ambition and unrelenting determination to his beliefs with a charisma that makes him one of the most memorable characters in all of gaming. His attitude towards government and religious officials, which he refers to as “parasites,” heavily mirrors the objectivist beliefs Ayn Rand expressed in novels like Atlas Shrugged. The inclusion of these philosophical themes elevates Bioshock above the stereotype that games produce stories with little to no substance. 	Unfortunately, the story’s only flaw, and the main drawback of the game in general, is the ending, which feels abrupt and underwhelming compared to the rest of the game. Luckily, the rest of the story makes up for the lackluster ending with some amazing plot twists that will stick with the player long after their experience with the game has concluded. 	If Bioshock’s mesmerizing plot doesn’t draw the player into its world, then its unparalleled presentation will. Every inch of Rapture is painstakingly rendered with borderline obsessive attention to the tiniest details. Water realistically drips from the walls and ceilings. Neon signs flicker and short out. Cheerful announcements fall on deaf ears over the intercom. These fully realized details add to the idea that Rapture was once a thriving metropolis where people lived happy and fulfilling lives, making its current state of disrepair all the more heart wrenching. Furthermore, Bioshock exudes a distinct art direction rarely seen in games. Rapture’s consistent Art Deco style will generate a sense of appreciation for the artistry required to bring these environments to life. 	While Bioshock’s story and presentation already place it in a league of its own, the game truly shines in its innovations to traditional FPS gameplay. Throughout the game, the player gather’s a diverse arsenal of weapons, ranging from a pistol to a shotgun to a flamethrower. Aiming and firing each of these weapons feels natural and satisfying. Also, all of the weapons can be upgraded to increase their accuracy and damage among other traits. However, Bioshock deviates from FPS norms with the addition of plasmids. These genetic modifications provide the player with a wide variety of powers, such as setting enemies on fire, picking up and throwing large objects, and possessing enemies to have them fight on the player’s side. In order to obtain these perks, the player must collect a gene altering substance called ADAM from small girls called Little Sisters that freely roam Rapture’s halls. However, the player must first defeat the Little Sisters’ guardians, huge diving suit wearing creatures simply known as Big Daddies. These intimidating monsters deal massive damage and will take a long time to defeat, but the satisfaction and rewards make it worth the effort. Once the Big Daddy falls, the player has the option to either harvest the Little Sister, which gives the player more ADAM but kills the girl, or rescue it, which yields less ADAM but promises the player a future reward. These decisions not only affect the player’s access to plasmids but also have moral ramifications that play into how the game’s story unfolds. This morality based choice system not only presents the player with an interesting dilemma with tangible consequences, but also perfectly ties into the game’s overall themes of personal growth and freedom.When all of Bioshock’s elements come together into a singular piece, they form a thoroughly entertaining and thought provoking experience that only a work of art can provide. The story keeps players guessing and presents them with philosophical concepts that other games can only dream of expressing. The presentation engrosses players into a world so authentically realized that it becomes as deep and complex as any of the game’s characters. Finally, the multifaceted gameplay forces the players to make decisions that impact their individual endeavors in unexpected ways. If this is the only time gamers experience the medium as a true art form, I can easily say that Bioshock deserves that distinction. Whether you’re a seasoned gamer or a curious onlooker, you owe it to yourself to pick up this slice of gaming excellence.

												Review for Bioshock 2: Here.Review for Bioshock 2 Remastered: Here.**Note: This is NOT a review for the Remastered version.If you would like to see my Bioshock Remastered review, please click here.*Excuse the play hours. I've much more on console and the Remastered version.From the very day that it was released, Bioshock was a classic in its own right. It came at the right time, when the over-saturated shooter genre was steadily getting more stale as time progressed. The title found overwheming acclaim due to its fresh gameplay, unique story, and immersive setting. Often called the spiritual successor to System Shock 2, Bioshock is the title that put developer/publisher 2K Games on the road to success. The only real question here is... would you kindly?Even though Bioshock was originally released in 2007, the game has aged remarkably well. Many were surprised to hear that Remastered versions of the first two titles were underway, as the graphics have held up superbly over nearly a decade. While the console versions of the game ran flawlessly, the PC port did come with its share of issues; most notably mouse acceleration problems, but also a handful of glitches that cause one to have to reload their save files. Unfortunately, these problems were never patched out despite how easy they could've been to fix.Welcome to Rapture. The year is 1960. You are a man named Jack, aboard an airplane flying over the Atlantic Ocean. The plane goes down, and surrounded by fire and debris you swim to a nearby lighthouse. Upon entering, you're greeted by a man named Atlas via radio, after being threatened by horrendously insane denizens of the underwater city. In a somewhat submarine type of contraption called a Bathysphere, you submerge down what is assumed to be thousands of fathoms under the sea, where you enter the rustic, dystopian, Art Deco style city of Rapture.At first the player isn't given much information on the character that they're playing, nor much of the story for that matter. The story progresses through a series of audio interactions with Atlas, and through collection audio diaries that are scattered throughout each level. Occasionally, other characters present themselves over the communication radio, and there are only a small handful of cutscenes which are placed at very appropriate moments. Without taking the time to explore Rapture and find all of the diaries, one may feel slightly lost in terms of plot and story. If you take the time to find and listen to all 122 diaries, it's easy to say that 2K did an amazing job adding depth and vibrancy to each character.As stated before, Bioshock has a very unique approach to gameplay. Not only do you get six upgradable weapons (shotgun, pistol, chemical thrower, crossbow, etc.), but you get 11 Plasmids to play around with; however, you can only equip 7 at any given time, but you can swap out what Plasmids and Tonics you have equipped at a Gene Swap Station. Plasmids rewrite your DNA, and infuse you with outstanding powers such as Telekinesis, Incineration, Insect Swarms, and even the ability to Hypnotize Big Daddy. In order to use Plasmids, you must have enough Eve, which can be gained through injecting yourself with Eve Hypos. It's the same basic concept as spells and mana. However, Jack's left hand changes aesthetics with each newly equipped Plasmid, and there are also upgrades to find for most of them.Suffice it to say that the game has a lot of variety to offer, especially given its age. The enemies that you will encounter are as equally unique, and they are known as Splicers. People who have been surgically modified to the extreme, whether willingly or forced, by the insane Dr. Steinman. There are a total of five different Splicers, each with their own unique attributes. However, let us not forget the star of the show here, the Big Daddy. There are two different kinds of Big Daddies, Bouncer and Rosie. Their role is to protect the Little Sisters who are harvesting ADAM around Rapture. You must face these behemoths each time that you want to either rescue or harvest a Little Sister.ADAM is another type of currency in Bioshock, although you also have money that you collect for buying items and ammo, and it is used to unlock new Tonics, Plasmids, new slots for each, and upgrades for both Health and Eve. The more Little Sisters you either harvest or rescue, the more ADAM you collect. I should also mention here that Tonics function as your abilities, and they can also have several findable upgrades akin to the Plasmids; there are well over 50 Tonics in total throughout the game. There's also a very limited crafting system in place, so that you can find components and make ammo, new Tonics, and even autohack devices to assist in hacking Turrets, Security Bots, Cameras, and Vending Machines.However, despite everything that has been aforementioned, the real ingredient that makes this game stand out so vividly is its amazing art direction and thick, immersive atmosphere. One really gets hit hard with the authentic 1960's vibe, which is conveyed through the Art Deco style of the game. However, instead of it being a pristine environment, Rapture is decayed, down-trodden, flooded, and rusty. At almost every corner you're reminded that you're hundreds, if not thousands, of fathoms below the surface, and at the same time you're constantly reminded of the time period; whether it be visually or by way of music. There's not a lot of music in the game, but there are aptly placed jukeboxes from time to time that sing relevant tunes from the time period. One of the hardest hitters is looking out of any given window and seeing a neon sign lit city underwater.If you've never taken the time to visit Rapture and delve into the universe of Bioshock, you shouldn't wait any longer. The story is absolutely remarkable, and one that you will not forget for years to come; I haven't played this title since 2007, and its story, influence, and artistic direction have never left me. There is a ton to do in Rapture, and a large amount of places to explore, looking back on it now it's pretty crazy how many mechanics and features that 2K were able to implement into the title; especially being such a smaller team a decade ago. Now, would you kindly go and play Bioshock? "With the sweat of your brow, Rapture can become your city as well." - Andrew Ryan.Rating: 5.0/5.0 - An astonishing achievement, this game must be played.𐌕𐋏𐌄 𐋏𐍈𐍂𐍂𐍈𐍂 𐌽𐌄𐌕𐤔𐍈𐍂𐌊 Curator | Group 𐌂𐌋𐌆𐌂𐌊 𐌅𐍈𐍂 𐌾𐍈𐍂𐌄

												Here's my 2nd review of the 'best FPS's of all time', as promised.(Bragging note: dont mind my Playtime of the game on Steam, i played and did 100% on all 3 Bioshock games on the PS3)Bioshock is the most stylish game of all time.While HL2 is the traditional FPS, great in every department, but following previously established archetypes, Bioshock revolutionizes most of those formulas. So i'll also try my best to 'stylize' my 'review formula':Rapture.Truly, this amazing underwater city defines everything this game does well. From the very start, you feel like Alice, going into the rabbit hole, into Wonderland... Except you're late for this one, it's already in ruins.The art style is absolutely amazing, the 20's Art Déco combined with the sci fi / mechanical aspects results in a sense of confusion, not knowing if you're in the past or future, which adds to the mysterious tone of the ruined city.The combat system is also very refreshing, instead of just relying on weapons, they added plasmids, which can be mixed with the guns for fun gameplay, with an added layer of depth. The exploration and scavenging were a nice surprise for me (as an obsessive explorer in gaming), presenting both some RPG elements and the backstory of the city, before it collapsed (metaphorically), through the eyes of its previous inhabitants.Another unique, iconic element of the game is it's enemies, more specifically the almighty Big Daddy, who provides an amazing dynamic to the combat (i was gonna describe it, but i decided it's best to let the players found out for themselves).Finally we reach the Story, praised as one of the best in videogames, proving that FPS's dont have to be mindless with virtually no story (you guys know what games im talking about!), by presenting complex philosophical, moral and political ideas, as an amazing social commentary that should probably be studied and debated by the experts of those departments. All of this, with a limited amount of characters, that you can count witth the fingers in your hands. But even though few, each counts as a hundred, with powerful personalities crashing, which results in the infamous plot twists that catapulted this game into stardom.Now, would you kindly do yourself a favor, and go play this game immediately, if you havent yet (or even if you have!)

			Views: 1,805		

			Bioshock is a FPS set in the underwater city of Rapture and it also has quite a few RPG elements such as customizable abilities and upgrades.		

I started playing Bioshock thinking it would be a straightforward FPS with no depth, but I can tell you that I was pleasantly surprised by it.Both the setting and the story were really engaging which got me really immersed in the game. Everything from the shooting mechanics to the spectacular voice acting gave the game a really polished feel.The game isn't as linear as I originally thought, some points you're forced to scavenge for ammo and you actually get rewarded for exploring which is really nice.You can also really customize how you play by selecting from a huge choice of plasmids which change your character in interesting ways.One tiny thing that annoyed me is that there's absolutely no penalty for dying, you just respawn at the checkpoint losing absolutely no progress or money. Also, there are very frequent hacking puzzles which broke the pace of the gameplay.Finally, the ending of the game was highly anticlimactic. It spends ages immersing you just to end it all with an escort mission and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ excuse of a -Beep-, climaxing with a 30 second cinematic.If you don't mind a minigame every now and then, or a somewhat rushed ending then I'm sure you'll enjoy the great gameplay and many plot twists that this game offers. I really enjoyed my time with Bioshock and it's one of the best single player FPS games I've ever played, so it gets a 7 out of 10 on 60 Second Reviews.

content:
ry 6, 2015
												Would you kindly read this review and buy this game? If you didn't know, BioShock is claimed to be one of the most revolutionary FPS's games of all time, and that statement has plently of truth to it. It exceeds in almost all areas, but no gem is without its flaws. Unfortunately for BioShock, these flaws can be quite noticeable when you come across to them. DO NOT let that discourage you from playing this game though; it's an experience you don't want to miss.In terms of presentation, BioShock fails to unimpress. The view of the underwater city of Rapture will amaze you when it emerges on your screen, and the steampunk art style is very unique, while being consistent throughout the game. Voice acting is perfect without a doubt, and characters such as Ryan Andrew and Sander Cohen will leave a lasting impression long after you finish the game. Sound design is extremly well-done as well: the whale-like moans from the hulking Big Daddies are very creepy, and the game only uses music for atmospheric reasons, adding an extra layer of immersion that makes the game quite screepy, but never outright scary (which is not what the game is trying to do).The story is the main highlight of BioShock, and presents themes and ideologies that are very applicable to reality, mainly the view of objectivism. Plot twists and unforgetable characters will make the experience a memorable ones, and each audio-diary will flesh out the world of Rapture, especially in events following up to the game. As for the main protagonist Jack, he's the typical silent playable character that every shooter seems to have, but his background information makes him quite interesting. Despite this, the story is damned near perfect, even if it feels ever-so rushed after the games huge revelation and twist.I could end the review here, as the story is something that alone should be able to sell this game instantly, no strings attached. However, how does BioShock sell as an FPS? The game features an arsenal of weapons from a flamethrower to a machine gun, and are all quite standard. The sense of conserving ammo that the game has at first is very intense, however later on you will have more money than you even need, so that feeling is somewhat lost. Gunplay feels slightly "floaty" (can't really get my finger on what it is), and later on becomes quite inneffective against enemies that suddenly have increased durability from earlier in the game. Speaking of enemies, you'll encounter Splicer's, humans which are addicted to this substance called ADAM, which grants them superpowers but makes them mentally unstable. Some will teleport around you, while others will have a box of grenades to utilize instead. But most significant of all are the Big Daddies.These hulking beasts present a real challenge, but are neutral if not dealt with. Why? They guard Little Sisters. which are key to the games plot and whether you get a good or bad ending. These altered girls harvest ADAM from dead corpses (and have a creepy sense of innocence to them), and you have the option to either save them or harvest them. Saving leads to the good ending but you get less ADAM, and harvesting them leads to the bad ending but you get more ADAM (and a combination leads to the sad ending). Actually combating the Big Daddies leads to a great deal of planning, and you'll have to acknowledge that you wont come out of the fight without a few scars.Going backwards, do you recall how I noted how guns became less useful as the game progresses? Well, that is because of Plasmids, which are basically superpowers like shooting flames, bolts of electricity, or even a swarm of bees! These are incredibly fun to use. een though you have to switch to your Plasmids and use them independantly from your weapons, making combat feel slightly clunky. The game also presents you with many RPG features, such as a hacking minigame (meh), weapon/plasmid upgrades, shops, ammo types, and plenty of nooks and cranies to add to it all. Overall combat is slightly outdated by todays standards (no sprint or ADS, if such a thing would bother you), but is still incredibly fun regardless.SLIGHT GAMEPLAY SPOILERS AHEADAnd here is a warning to where the game goes wrong. Following the huge plot twist at the end of the second third of the game, the gameplay plummets (pun intended) downhill, even though it may not seem so at first. It places some annoying restrictions on your abilities, but that's where the fun begins. After that you have a boring and confusing (IMO) scavenger hunt, and after that an incredibly dull escort mission before a forgetable (but not as bad as the scavenger hunt) final boss. To be fair, the only part that really stuck out as bad to me was the scavenger hunt: everything before it was annoying but still fun, and after it forgetable. The audio diaries and story will certainly make up for it however, as the games presentation remains consistent throughout.BioShock is a prime example of how video games are art, and is one you should not overlook. Even where it missteps in gameplay, it's story and presentation are grand throughout, and provide a unique experience you will not forget and will come back to again and again. There is no denying that BioShock is a game that will stand the test of time, and I would give it a 9/10 (If it was story alone than 11/10, it's that good). So, would you kindly get it?

												Bioshock is a great game. It's polished, gritty, tense and sometimes frightening. It's also quite wordy and philosophical. There's a lot to like here. The sound, especially, is amazing, and the graphics are beautiful.The game promises a "play it your way" experience, and succeeds, to a point. The many plasmids (think "spells") encourage you to try different tactics, but the very first combo you learn is the easiest and most effective: shock your opponent, and then bludgeon him with a wrench while he's stunned. It’s generally easy to identify a best plasmid to use for each situation; although you can explore others. I should also point out that this game is psychologically very taxing. You spend a great deal of time looting dead, mangled, burned corpses. You're crawling through a destroyed city. The game is oppressive and claustrophobic, and seriously depressing. I was glad when it was over, but also glad to have played it. Difficult at the time, but it left a lasting impression.

content:
, 2014
												Call me late to the party, by about seven years, but Bioshock is a perfect example of all that is good in gaming and stands tall as one of the greatest games of human history.Coming into the game with the mindset of someone who played and loved Bioshock Infinite, I set my mind back to 2007 when the game was released: Measuring it up to the standards back then, the result? I was completely blown away.Bioshock was ahead of it's time with amazing graphics, fluid gameplay, immersive environments and a story that left me on the edge of my seat in anticipation. Taking the role of Jack, a silent protagonist you venture deeper and deeper into the eery and unsettling depths of the underwater city of Rapture, radio contact directs you to your goals and you can find audiographs to learn more about the history of such an incredible city. The environments feel isolated, making the player feel trapped and uncomfortable and sets up for a terrifying setting where you square down with the mutated and insane denizens still roaming the submerged streets.  The balance between environment and story are so perfectly intuned that it is easy to lose yourself in the setting and be completely immersed in the story, sinking hours at a time into unlocking the secrets this modern Atlantis leaves to find, building up to one of the most shocking twists you will ever experience. The story, lore and setting of the entire game is incredible, and when you finish playing through the game I highly recommend going online and reading up more, because the history of Rapture is so well written that I can spend days scratching around to find every little tidbit of information.To defend yourself you are given a large arsenal of firearms and Plasmids (genetic modification tonics that alter your very DNA and give you powerful abilities) that you can use in many ways: Set up traps and take advantage of the environment to maximize the damage potential of plasmids, or you can use your guns to plow through your foes in a very satisfying way, as each and every firearm has a good feel to it and carries a wonderful punch. As you progress in the game, enemies get tougher and tougher, requiring more firepower to take them out. Throughout the game you can collect and combine upgrades to your weapons giving them more damage output as well as numerous other bonuses such as recoil reduction or firing rate (at the same time giving your weapon a visible upgrade, making them look absurdly bad-♥♥♥), as well as gene tonics that you use to give yourself powerful buffs to your combat and hacking expertise.The level design is flawless, being understandable but far from straightforward; offering plenty of opportunites to explore and loot, finding every little scrap of ammo and utilities to give yourself as much of an advantage as possible. Now I have to apologize, but there is one part about Bioshock that wasn't perfect and if I can say so safely: was bad. I'M SORRY I'M SORRY I DON'T WANT TO SAY IT BUT I FEEL I NEED TO POINT THIS OUT.So be advised, mild spoiler alert: Skip this paragraph over if you do not wish to have spoilers.In the later stages of the game you partake in (ugh) an escort mission. One of the types of missions that gamers almost universally despise on a molecular level. The objective is to guide a little girl through a splicer infested area and protect the little rat because she's the only one who can open the doors for you. Now the flaws with this is that throughout the game up to this point you set the pace yourself, you moved, fought and explored as you saw fit, because this was your experience and you experienced it as you wanted: Then this little bedwetter waddles in and sets the pace for you, robbing you of your control  as she struts thoughtlessly into automated turrets and other dangers. But the worst part is that the nosepicker is just about one of the most annoying characters I've ever seen: She repeats the same small handful of dialogue over and over without end, and practically NEVER SHUTS UP. I honestly wanted to shoot her myself, but I seemingly needed her to open the doors for me, to which I wanted to physically pick her up and use her as a battering ram. This portion, although short-lived, felt so far out of place and was a blemish on an otherwise perfect game.Finally, Bioshock was built on an outdated engine, which results in some game-breaking issues as a result of incompatabilites with modern technology, such as inconsistent mouse sensitivity and flat-out broken audio. To which I refer you to these guides on Steam that have both solved these issues:Mouse sensitivity - http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=129822360Audio fix - http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=178202642With thanks to the creators for their help, without them I would have never been able to experience this beautiful game. So in conclusion: Bioshock is a great experience that has triumphed over the test of time, with an atmosphere, gameplay and story that has earned it critical praise. I do not only recommend Bioshock, I worship Bioshock as a shining beacon to all that is good in gaming.

ber 19, 2015
												"We all make choices, but in the end our choices make us."Bioshock is a hell of a game I'll give it that. A first person shooter with RPG elements and a knack for scaring you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.+The graphics look beautiful for a game that came out in 2007. Sure the textures aren't great, and the characters are a little cartoony, but everything about the aesthetic of this game helps to fully set the atmosphere. And take my word for it, this is one of the most immersive games I have played in a very long time when it comes to the atmosphere. +The soundtrack is phenomenal. It fits every single scene. It helps draw you into the game. It can make even a bathroom that lacks jump scares the most terrifying place you've ever tip-toed your way into. +The level design is fantastically done, if poorly translated onto a 2D map. The underwater city of rapture has a mild claustrophobic feeling to it, but it makes sense. It fits the setting quite well, and when you need space? You can usually find or make it.+The story is fantastic, Ken Levine does wonders with stories. Draw dropping plot twists and endings that'll leave you speechless, i loved every second of it. There isn't a story in the world Ken Levine could write that I could forget.+Decent-length. Got 21 hours out of the game after getting it for $1 in a bundle. Definitely worth the price. I was partially a completionist however, I explored almost every single room and shelf in Rapture. I also moved very slowly at points since I scare easy.+Since the tags say it's horror, I can tell you it really does horror right. Jump-scares when you least expect them. And a very creepy atmosphere that doesn't rely on jump scares to begin with.-Respawning enemies. Just...ugh. Bioshock as a series is infamous for throwing enemies, and bullet sponges at you. If it bothers you, play on a lower difficulty, you'll become a bullet sponge yourself.-Bugs with Win7 or later. From random crashes (That lead to all of your settings resetting) to the sounds cutting out when too make sound sources are coming in at once. Most noticeable when guardians of rapture (Sounds better than dinky flying robots) are shooting. Especially noticeable towards the end of the game. Immersion-breaking to say the least...but not game-breaking.All in all, this game holds up. I'm very glad I made my easy-to-scare ♥♥♥ finish the game, as it was totally worth it. Keeping its buggy state and flaws in mind, I give this game an 4/5. I think this is a game that everyone who enjoys a good immersive story should play. Were the bugs fixed, I'd give it a 9/10, so maybe a console version might fare better for you. Either way, I have to admit that it is an amazing game and it has defined the standards for the horror FPS genre. Now, would you kindly consider giving it a try? =)

er 26, 2014
												I was skeptical at first, since I started the series with Infinite and ended up not liking that game. Fortunately I decided against my bias and purchased this one.One thing I love about Bioshock, is the way it tells or rather shows you the story and events in Rapture. Infinite in my humble opinion felt way too scripted, and it bugged me, how often that particular game took away my control over Bookers' character. Bioshock instead opts for a different way of handling this aspect by letting me, the player decide wether I want to give attention to a cutscenes or not, what I really like. Bioshock also features a very engaging story, that might surprise you.Despite a somewhat "antique" Unreal Engine 2, the game is a stunner, providing incredible (and unsettling) setpieces. Unfortunately ragdoll and physic animations are capped at 30FPS which really makes them stick out like a sore thumb. The games' biggest problem however are the low FOV and the ridiculously low weapon FOV, which made me motionsick after 5 minutes of playtime. This can be avoided by using a tool called "Flawless Widescreen" which allows the user to customize both options. Irrational Games did a great job on Bioshocks artdesign which still holds up even to this date. The music and soundeffects are well done and provide a good atmosphere.Bioshocks gunplay is alright. The player is given a rather large arsenal of weaponary and plasmids. The guns felt a bit too weak, which turned some enemies into frustrating bulletsponges. My favourites are the wrench and the shotgun, which I found useful for all situations they game would throw at me. Plasmids are integrated well into the gameplay and are lots of fun to use, even though "Elektroshock" turned out to be a bit too OP (extremely handy for foighting Big Daddies).I do have an issue with the health system. Even with a full inventory of health kits, I happened to die alot because there is little to no feedback when you're low on health. The bar isn't visible enough due to its rather small size and is in my opinion badly positioned (upper left corner). It would have been nice if the player was given the option to customize the HUD to their likings.The game happened to run very badly on my PC. It crashed alot, never saved my settings and featured horrid mouse acceleratrion issues. The DX10 features are responsible for Bioshock not working properly on newer machines, I advise to set the game to DX9 (add "-dx9" to the start options). Fixes for this game can be found on the PCGamingWiki.I had a lot of fun with Bioshock and can safely recommend it to anyone who like to play First Person Shooters.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Ich war Anfangs etwas skeptisch über dieses Spiel, da ich Infinite vorher gespielt und nicht genossen habe. Gott sei Dank habe ich mich aber letztendlich doch zum Kauf des ersten Teils entschieden.Was mir an Bioshock sehr gefällt, ist die Art und Weise, wie die Geschichte und die Geschehnisse in Rapture erzählt oder besser, gezeigt werden. Infinite hatte meiner Meinung zuviele geskriptete Szenen, was mich sehr genervt hat, da mir einfach zu oft die Kontrolle über Booker entnommen wurde. Bioshock hingegen verzichtet auf diese Vorgehensweise und lässt den Spieler entscheiden, ob er einer Cutscene beiwohnen möchte oder nicht, was ich sehr begrüße. Zudem wartet das Spiel mit einer sehr fesselnden Handlung auf, welche den einen oder anderen zu überraschen vermag.Trotz veralteter Unreal Engine 2 sieht das Spiel fantastisch aus. Man bekommt sehr schöne (zum Teil auch sehr schaurige) Setpieces geboten. Ragdoll und Physikanimationen werden nur in 30FPS dargestellt, was nicht ins Gesamtbild passen möchte und schlecht aussieht. Das größte Problem des Spiels ist jedoch die niedrige FOV sowie das viel zu niedrige Waffen-FOV. Nach nur 5 Minuten habe ich große Übelkeit verspürt. Das Programm "Flawless Widescreen" ist hier zu empfehlen, mit dem man beide FOV-Optionen nach Belieben anpassen kann. Das Artdesign von Bioshock ist Irrational Games sehr gut gelungen und lässt das Spiel auch heute noch gut aussehen. Die Musik und Soundeffekte passen gut in das Spiel rein und verleihen es eine solide Atmospähre.Bioshocks' Gunplay ist passabel. Es wird dem Spiel ein üppiges Aresnal an Feuerwaffen und Plasmiden geboten. Die Feuerwaffen sind meiner Meinung nach etwas zu schwach, was einige Gegner zu echten Bulletsponges gemacht hat. Meine Favoriten waren die Rohrzange und die Schrotflinte, welche sich bei allen Situationen bewährt haben. Plasmide sind gut eingebunden und machen extrem viel Spaß anzuwenden, wobei die Fähigkeit "Elektroshock" doch ziemlich overpowered ist (extrem hilfreich gegen Big Daddies).Ein Kritikpunkt den ich habe ist das Gesundheitssystem. Trotz reichlichen Vorrat an Verbandskästen bin ich häufig abgekratzt aufgrund fehlendem Feedback bei niedriger Gesundheitsanzeige. Die Anzeige im HUD ist nicht gerade groß und meiner Meinung nach flasch positioniert (oben links). Wäre ganz nett gewesen, wenn man das HUD umgestalten könnte.Das Spiel hat am Anfang auf meinem Rechner Probleme gemacht. Es stürzte oft ab, hat meine Einstellungen nicht gespeichert und hatte extrem gräßliche Mausbeschleunigung. Die DX10 Features verursachen Probleme auf neuen Rechnern, deshalb rate ich Bioshock im DX9 Modus zu spielen ("-dx9" in die Startoptionen einfügen). Im PCGamingWiki findet man alle Informationen und Fixes für das Spiel.Ich hatte auf jeden Fall sehr viel Spaß mit Bioshock und kann es jedem Spieler, der First Person Shooter mag, empfehlen.

Product received for free
												I don’t know since when PC gamers become this picky and that difficult to impress, but this remastered version isn’t that bad, I feel it receives overwhelming negative reviews like this is not fair.Unlike a large number of steam users out there who have next-gen alien technology powered Titan weapons to fire, my pc is old and can’t launch most of the AAA titles games come out now days(I play AAA titles on console), I usually play some naïve pixel graphics games on my vantage skeleton PC . After reading so many thumb down reviews, I couldn’t stop wondering, ‘is this remastered version that bad?’ So I decided to give it a try myself to see it through. Thought it would not be able to launch since my PC barely reaches the minimum requirements to play. It turned out ironically. I got in game with no issues at all. It runs perfectly smooth on my PC, my key binding was just fine and did not encounter any functional break down. The sensation of the mouse is not at its best but far away from horrible to control. It did not mix up with my controller either. My game did not crash once. I arrived Repture safe and sound. Honestly, I’ve tried to experience any issues players here had raged, but I had met none. The only fair point so far I’ve agreed is: This version doesn’t look that much different from the original. But I wasn’t in the right place to grumble this, since if the graphics were improved to the next-gen level, I probably wouldn’t be able to launch this game by any chance.The developers have my respect and sympathy. They’ve made products for the most of their customers (original game owners including me) for free, now they are rampaging. Their new potential customers now are wondering around because the game got mixed reviews, their decisions are uncertain.Honestly, I’d say: If you don’t own Bioshock franchise and would like to get them, this remastered version is definitely better than the original ones. At least, they’ve added steam achievements for Bioshock 1 and pretty fun museum exhibition mode in game. Of course, if it had trading cards and badges and creepy profile background would be brilliant, but maybe they will add it later, who knows? As someone received these 2 remastered games for free, I thank the development team’s efforts and 2K to bring them here. I am not a fangirl of Bioshock franchise, but I knew it is a masterpiece. I don’t play many FPS games, but it doesn’t mean they are not good because my personal taste isn’t there.Scarlet’s Score: 8.0/10(I haven’t got enough time to play this game till the end, so I can’t give exact the full review of the gameplay. However, for a timeless FPS known as Bioshock, an 8 point is fair to where it’s standard lies)

Formal Rating : 9/10User Rating : Superb plot,INSTABUYDate of the review : 05/26/2014 Bioshock.Well,i played BI first and then i tried this one,and i can clearly admit that i enjoyed this one way more than Bioshock Infinite.Why?Strongest plot,strongest gameplay.I loved every second of my playthrough.I couldn't stop pressing F12,i took like 60 photos,because in every room,there was something interesting.A corpse,a painting,a quote,you know,these kind of things.Plus,this game got its creepy moments too.For example dead corpses which are not really dead,Or rooms with creepy stuff like,toilets with not-so-much-light,or weird statuary.Anyway,lets continue on the details.Plot : 10/101960, and you're flying over the Atlantic Ocean. One mysterious plane crash later, you're floating in the water, apparently the lone survivor, surrounded by the flaming wreckage of the aircraft. But there's a lighthouse on a tiny island just at the edge of your view.Your only chance is to get there.and so you do.inside,you find a submersible called bathysphere,which only purpose is to get you into the void of the sea.You don't have a choice,so you pull the trigger,the door closes,and you get down...down..There you find a secret city,underwater,named Rapture.An underwater city created by Andrew Ryan,with her own rules,her own freedom.However,everything has gone completely wrong.The city is vandalised,destroyed,and deadly lunatics roam the paths of Rapture.Apart from the phreaks,little girls named ''little sisters'' who contain the corrupting substance called ADAM move through the city with their ''protectors'' ''Big Daddies'',some people with a huge armor. Gameplay : 9/10Character Customization.nope,i dont mean you can change your appearance,however,you can find ''magical powers'' which can be shot out of your fingers,elemental powers such as electricity,Ice,fire,wind,even BEES (no,not the bees).Those powers consume EVE(mana).You can use your powers to control your enemies against your other enemies,you can use them to gain control of machines such as turrets.Also,you got a variety of purchasable talents,which variety from Engineering,Physical,and Combat talents.each kind of talents got a different use,for example there's a physical talents which makes you swing your melee weapon faster.You start with 2 slots for every category of talents,and you can purchase more from a Gatherer's Garden .There are 8 types of weapons,1 melee,6 guns,and a camera,which doesnt deal any damage,however it is used to take photographs of your enemies,so you can learn more about them and find new methods of dealing with them.There are 3 types of bullets for every gun,the normals,the armor penetration ones (against machines and big daddies) and the Antipersonnel ones which are useful against lunatics etc. You are also able to find weapon upgrade machines,which will make your weapons more powerful.You can hack vents,safes,or even turrets to help you defeat your enemies.There are 2 types of ''money'' the normal money,and the consumable ADAM which give you new powers or slots or even higher health.ADAM can be used on a different kind of vent,the Gatherer's Garden.You can consume ADAM from the little sister,by either saving them(you will earn less,however everytime you complete a series of 3 ''rescues'' you will earn a surprise),or killing them.Finally,You collect audio logs which help you understand more whats going on.Graphics : 8/10I cant say i went crazy about the graphics,however Bioshock got some nice atmosphere.Controls : 8/10Easy Enough,however at the begining i got a little confused.Audio : 10/10Incredible voice acting,making the game stick greatly with the plot.Great soundtracks,but the thing i loved about the audio,is the music which plays when you rescue a little sister.its both beautiful and cute.

I picked it up again this week, and couldn't put it down until I finished. For whatever reason, I complety misjudged this game, I really reccomend you play this masterpeice.

												New to FPS on PC (so I beat the game on easy mode like the scrub I am)(easy mode is pretty friggin easy)First thing is that if there are a couple compatibility issues with Win10. You have to find the .exe file and run on compatibility mode for Windows XP 2/3. There's a couple other compatibility issues, and certain things will make your game (and computer) bug out, but it's not that big of a deal.The first thing you see when you start the game is an ominous entryway into the city; your plane crashes near some sort of towering structure, and the inside doesn't light up until you enter and the double doors close behind you. You slowly descend, the lights flickering on as you proceed, and eventually you get to the bathysphere and begin your journey to the underwater city.The opening scene is just *twang* mmm, delicious. The initial events set up the expectations for the rest of the game quite nicely. The entire city seems to be the worn-down remnants of some wonderfully fun place, very carnival-esque with all its glowing neon signs and jingles, but teeming with crazy people spiked on 'plasmids,' which I'm going to explain as genetic modifiers that allow you (and them) to use superhuman abilities such as zapping people with lightning, telekinesis, etc.For anyone looking to create a world of their own, play through Bioshock and pay attention - this game gets many things right.As for gameplay, you tend to have to do a lot of scavenging. Money, ammo, other resources, are all fairly difficult to come by unless you scrounge up everything in an area, including searching dead bodies and checking for weapons near recently deceased attackers (seriously, you have to figure out where they dropped the gun before you can claim their ammo). If you really do search everything and you're good about not wasting too many resources, you can end up with a lot of excess, so it's not too bad.The controls are a tad complicated because there are two 'categories' of weapons for you to use and multiple weapons for each category, but there are enough keyboard shortcuts that you can set everything up and be able to manage everything pretty quickly.There are a variety of ways to handle enemies that can be pretty fun - hacking security bots, for instance. Igniting gasoline makes everything catch on fire, water spreads lightning, and other such interactions. The only thing I don't really like is the security camera things. Maybe I'm just blind, but I have never spotted a security camera before it's spotted me, so I have to deal with these security bots for a full minute while the alarm blares, every single time.The story itself was underwhelming, because of its considerable reputation for having an incredible story. No, the story is not incredible. It's pretty good, definitely not bad. But not incredible. What I'm going to praise instead of the story is everything else - the aesthetics of the game are really good. The VOs, the characters, the sounds, the environment, and game progression compliment the story very well.Final score 8/10. Very fun gameplay, great voicework, a wonderfully carnival-esque world of horror, and also very nice music and sound. The song about some lady looking to buy a doggy with a waggily tale is still stuck in my head.btw pro tip - when you're choosing between 'harvest' and 'rescue,' always choose 'rescue.' It'll be worth it.NOTE: I got the entire BioShock collection for 16 freaking dollars, so I'm going to be very lenient about any mishaps.

This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock then skip to Results and read from there.2K Games blows my mind with a phenomenal first person shooter that goes above and beyond to provide an incredibly experience. BioShock does something magical, beyond gameplay it the complete and total mind-♥♥♥♥. Story:A plane crashes in the middle of the ocean and you are the sole survivor. As you are swimming from the wreckage you notice a small tower standing. What does the tower offer, but the amazing city of Rapture. The underwater city is completely in ruins and everyone is completely mad, but why and how will you ever escape. As you maintain communications with one other sane person it is up to you to make sure you both can make it out alive. Campaign:The campaign occurs across a variety of different areas as you take pods to go between. Each area even has multiple zones within it which can either be cross very quickly or can take a long time. The difficulty scales brilliantly in this game, and you can go from Easy to Hard depending on the experience you want from the game. With multiple endings, depending on if you save all the little sisters or kill more than one. The campaign puts you to the test with an amazing story, secrets through the game, and multiple puzzles/challenges. The campaign is long and has fourteen levels, which vary in length and even include epic boss fights that put you to your wits. Gameplay:BioShock plays like a typical First Person Shooter in many ways, but mixes in elements of RPGs to give variety. You gain these abilities called plasmids which you can buy with Adam (a type of in game currency) that can give you spells or tonics which give you buffs. There are many different weapons which throughout the game you can upgrade to make the weapons more efficient. There are seven weapons (wrench, pistol, machine gun, shotgun, grenade launcher, chemical thrower, and crossbow) and a camera. Unlike in Dead Rising the camera in this game actually serves a purpose, making you stronger/more effective against enemies as you take more pictures.  I personally played this game on hard and used the wrench almost the entire time without plasmids, so you can really choose the way you want to play with BioShock; either running through guns blazing, or taking your time sneaking around. Results:BioShock is an amazing game that offers a brilliant campaign, beautiful story, and amazing gameplay. This game mixes RPG, Puzzles, and FPS all gift wrapped into one fantastic game. You can have an epic struggle playing the game on hard or just enjoy the story playing on easy. There are loads of secret recordings spread throughout the game that develop the story and keep offering you more. BioShock is completely worth every penny even at full price. If you are frugal like me, then just wait till it’s on sale as it totally will.Pros:+Brilliant story that provides incredible replay value.+Amazing combat system that allows you to choose how you play. (Either melee, guns blazing, or shooting magic everywhere)+Loads of guns that allow you to mix your strategy, each with three different ammo types.+A camera that allows you to increase your character strengths.+A solid campaign with fifteen different levels.+Secret recordings that give you more elements to the story and create a deeper experience+Loads of different tonics which allow you to buff yourself and enhance your gameplay experience+Loads of different plasmids that allow you to shoot electricity, fire, ice, and even bees. Cons:-The volume for the recordings cannot be adjusted, they use the same levels as the gameplay volume. (In order to hear the recordings I had to crank up my speakers and hide in a corner)

												If you're wondering whether or not to buy this game, then the answer is this: YES, ABSOLUTELY !Now, I don't normally like shooters and scary games, where your enemies jump at you out of the blue but the trailers and screenshots from BioShock have always appealed to me and I finally decided to go through with the purchase. This turned to be one of my best gaming-related decisions so far. From the intro, the game had me captivated. I immediately loved the atmosphere of Rapture, with its amazing art-deco architecture, and various locations (after all years since its release, the game still looks great), I could almost feel how it must have felt to walk in the shoes of the protagonists. This feeling was further enhanced by the music... Ohh yes, the music. Nothing builds an eerie atmosphere better than hearing a pleasant old-shool song, played as if from a vinyl disc, while exploring a blood-stained, ruined city. The game mechanics? Here, there is little to mention apart from the fact that it's a solid, well-balanced shooter with some RPG entwined in it. You;ll have plenty of weapons, plasmids and genetic upgrades along the game but when all is said and done, you will end up using your three favourites. Hacking mini-games get a tiny bit boring after some time, but you can easily skip some of them with the help of items found along the way.As far as graphics are concerned, I can only say that Irrational Games made wonders with Unreal Engine 3 and even now, even with almost minimum level of details, the game looks great.Storywise, as far as video games are concerned - it's a masterpiece. If you don't play BioShock, you're missing out on a great story. and that's notwithstanding the fact that after the main plot twist (somewhere aobut 3/4 of a game) the plot loses its momentum a little.Quick summary of advantages:+amazing design and atmosphere of Rapture+great soundtrack (music and voiceover alike)+easy to master, entertaining combat with many possibilities to take down enemies+brilliant storyline and memorable characters+the game graphics did not age muchSome disadvantages:-rubbish map, unintuitive journal (although you won't use the latter too much)-if you don't like it - can give you a jump sometimes-only a few types of enemies-some artificial limitations - money cap, no plasmid+weapon combo...One additional thought. If you're anxious that BioShock might be too scary for your tastes: don't worry. Just pluck up the courage and force yourself through the first two locations (like I had to :D) and from there, it will go al lot smoother. There are much fewer scary moments in the further part of the game and when they do appear, you will be able to predict them with ease.So, coming back to the start: play BioShock, enjoy the story. You won't regret it and the memory of Rapture will stay with you for long.

												I am starting to write reviews for the games in my library and I declare this one as my first.  I will divide my reviews into three parts and a comments section to keep things standardized.  I will do my best to give candid and brief reviews. Bioshock Review(Story)Do you have a choice?  This is the question Bioshock asks.  The game takes place in 1960, in an underwater city called Rapture.  The city is falling apart as civil war rages among its citizens.  As a nameless protagonist (who winds up in Rapture due to an accident), you meet and help numerous people as you learn more about what happened to the city leading up to the war.  There are good and evil choices to make and multiple endings to the main story that reflect your decisions.  The dialogue is well written and voice acting phenomenal.      (Gameplay)Bioshock is a first person shooter with most combat taking place in close quarters areas.  You alternate between conventional fire arms and powers called "plasmids" that allow you to shoot electricity from your hand, throw objects, etc.  The weapons  have multiple ammo types/firing modes/uses that are acquired through upgrade stations.  Likewise, plasmids can be upgraded and all feel unique.  Multiple play styles are available: go in guns balzing, set traps for enemies to walk into, hack turrets so they fight with you, or take a stealth approach.  Ammo, health, and crafting supplies are acquired from looting or use of vending machines strewn about.  One mechanic the first two Bioshock games are known for is enemy research.  In Bioshock, research is accomplished through taking photographs of enemies and filling your research bar.  Every time you reach a new level of research, you gain a damage boost against that particular enemy.  Ammo can get scarce sometimes.(Design)The art-deco/1950's/1960's America decor are very well done here.  The advertisements, record player music, items, even the bottles all fit the time period. The game can get scary at times too due to the atmoshpere and noises you hear as you creep around.  Nearly every object has its own physics.  Glass bottles clink, suitcases float in the water, and fire leaves furniture (and enemies) charred.  The sound design is excellent, though I have an issue when gunfire starts where sounds cut out due to everything going on.                    (Final Comments)    As the first in the series, Bioshock is a great game with good controls, great writing, and one-of-a-kind atmosphere.  The twist of the story is legendary in my mind and the dialogue will leave an impression on you.  Now, would you kindly stop reading my review and dive into Rapture.

												Bioshock is first-person shooter action game developed by Irrational Games, 2K known as Boston / Australia in 2007.The game takes place in the 60s. The player, Jack survives a plane crash and reaches the underwater city Rapture found in decay. There he must fight against mutated humans and capture the substance called ADAM inside little girls called Little Systers that are defended by powerful Divers called Big Daddies. This substance will let the player acquire genetic improvements .Bioshock was really surprising because it created a whole new world with incredible narrative. history is noteworthy . Despite maps are not huge, they have superlative art and there are so many things to do that you never get bored . Combat is frenetic, there are turrets and machines to be hacked that provide ammunition and resources , there are also hidden resources and tonics to search that provide a remarkable range of combat.Instead of just owning guns, machine guns, etc. , we find tonics fire , electric rays, clouds of bees or many other forms of attack. This mixed mechanism was fairly new and fun at the time and it succeded on a very good game, Dishonored (2012), that took this concept and adapted it well .The game has elements of stealth, survival horror and role. It also has an important political component simulating an ultra-capitalist alternative world in a city where there are no ethical dilemmas and took to end the arts , science and engineering , which led to its decline .It is one of the top ranked games of all time . It has two sequels. The bioshock 2 showing an ultra communist character and Bioshock infinite that develops in an aerial city. In Bioshock infinite political, religious and scientific plot led to the end in a very elaborate story. It´s still a must have game in 2016.The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360.
